title: 114_s3521
content: The "Respond, Innovate, Succeed, and Empower Act of 2016" or the "RISE Act of 2016" amends the definition of disability in the Higher Education Act of 1965 to support students with disabilities in college. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to adopt policies recognizing documentation of an individualized education program (IEP) as sufficient proof of disability. The Higher Education Act of 1965 now requires institutions to accept documentation such as an IEP, a plan under section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, a record of service from various educational entities, or a record/evaluation from a private school for individuals with disabilities. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates institutions to accept various forms of documentation for disability accommodations, including records from licensed professionals, other educational institutions, and service in the uniformed services. Institutions must have transparent policies for determining eligibility and disseminate this information to students, parents, and faculty. Institutions must have transparent policies for determining eligibility for disability accommodations and disseminate this information to students, parents, and faculty, including during student orientation and on a public website. Authorization of $10,000,000 in funds for the National Center for Information and Technical Support for Postsecondary Students with Disabilities under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require institutions to submit key data on undergraduate students with disabilities to the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System. This includes graduation rates and the number of students accessing accommodations. The Higher Education Act of 1965 now requires institutions to report data on undergraduate students with disabilities, including graduation rates and accommodation usage. Personally identifiable information is protected if the number of students is 10 or less. The amendments made by this Act will not change the definitions of "reasonable accommodation" or "record of impairment" under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, nor affect the rights or remedies provided under the Act.
